results.description:
Come and join us for an evening of fun and TurnOn. How often do we get an opportunity to be real with each other in NYC?


We play 3 communication game (you can play at whatever level feels comfortable to you). Imagine meeting new people in an environment where people felt comfortable to be themselves. That's what we have created.

It's a refreshing change from the typical networking or bar conversation.

You get the opportunity to examine yourself. Through other people putting quality attention on you, asking questions with genuine curiosity, and then listening - really listening – to your responses.

What comes up might surprise you!

At the end of the evening we will tell you all about how you can learn the practice of Orgasmic Meditation. What class you can take and what we have to offer so you can have the life that you want.

It's amazing how connected we can end up feeling - even in a room full of strangers - when we are willing to say what's real. In an hour and some you may even forget for a moment you are in New York City.

OneTaste NYC is an organization teaches Orgasmic Meditation, otherwise known as OM. The games we play at TurnON are designed to create the visceral sensation of Orgasm/OM in your body, without having to actually do the practice (or remove any clothing!).

It's a friendly invitation to play and push your edges in a way that feels good. This allows you to stretch yourself and inspires self-discovery!

Come early, doors close at 8:40p. COST TO ATTEND IS $10.

For questions contact [masked] |[masked]

Can't make this one? visit us at www.turnonny.us

results.description:
Futsal Pick up games (intermediate to advanced level)

Fee: $10 dollars per player per game; pay through paypal.

Only 10 players per game, no subs. One game is 55-60 minutes. Be early. Every player rotates as a Goalie for 6 minutes, time it with an electronic scoreboard. We play without a break. Regulation size goals with nets. Futsal ball. Please make sure to bring a white and a red t-shirt, indoor shoes. Games are competitive, but friendly. Please keep in mind that these games are definitely not for the beginners. 

Please no fouls, zero tolerance to this. “Futsal is not a physical but a technical game ”. Minimum physical contact means fewer injuries and no violence. No charging, no 

displacing with your arms or body to gain the position on the ball. No running into the opponent. Play the ball, not the player. Time it, don’t foul it. 

Refunds: Cancel your RSVP ,  24 hours or more before the game and we will make the refund. No refund for late cancelations; no exceptions. 

The school entrance is located on East 109th street between 2nd and 3rd avenues (near 2nd avenue) on the south side of the street. You'll see a row of 5-6 metal doors. Open the door or ring the buzzer (on your right) and someone will open the door for you.

For questions,  use the MEETUP message and notifications tools. 

Post pictures and videos at:

Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/Futsalacrossamerica?ref=hl

Twitter: https://twitter.com/FutsalAcrossA

Thank you for being part of Futsal Across America.

Enjoy the game!

Do you have enough time to do everything you want?

Paramahamsa Sri Nithyananda has said “Not having time is one of the worst forms of poverty.”

CLICK HERE TO REGISTER, SPACES ARE EXTREMELY LIMITED!

MUST CALL THE CENTER TO LET THEM KNOW YOU ARE COMING! SEE THE PHONE NUMBERS BELOW.


What if you could just shift your beliefs about time, and through that totally alter your relationship with time and the way you live your entire life?

What if the right understanding would make you so powerful you could just play with time, like a toy?

What if you knew the secret to have time for both everything you NEED to do and everything you WANT to do?

If you ever wished there was a way to just multiply your free time, and stop being so overwhelmed…

Then this is THE breakthrough you’ve been waiting for!

For the first time, the secrets and mysteries of time will be revealed by a living Enlightened Master, Paramahamsa Nithyananda in a brand new workshop!

2 DAY GUIDED MEDITATION WORKSHOP by a living Enlightened Master, Paramahamsa Nithyananda, about…CONQUERING TIME! Unlocking the illusion of time, so you have time for everything. Happening LIVE around the planet

results.description:
Sufi Ghazal Fusion Nite -  Fri Mar 4


“A never before seen night where the Poetic East meets Sounds from the West”

Live music by NJ/NY’s top artists performing Sufi music and ghazals fused with western sounds

-----------------------------------------------------------

9 pm to 10 pm - XOVER FUSION

featured : LUBOMIR & MADINA AMIN

-----------------------------------------------------------

Special Guest Performers - Lubomir & Madina Amin will be Performing a beautiful blend of Crossover Fusion Music.

Lubomir - is a classically trained Cellist/Guitarist gone rogue, utilizing Balkan instruments such as Gadulka, Kaval, Gaida together with Ableton live to create soundscapes reminiscent of both past and future.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bvOFQ3hInUw

Classically trained singer Madina Amin created a distinctive sound, a unique concept that incorporates classic vocal approach with array of ethno elements from Middle East, Balkans and her native Uzbek Mugham.

Madina Amin - released her first new album “Anticipation” in 2015 which included covers of famous singers like Sarah Brightman, Emma Shapplin, Josh Groban and original songs with arrangement of Oriental instruments.She’s working over a new EP World/Ethno album that will contain only original masterpieces with collaboration of a talented team of producers and world musicians.

On March 4, Madina Amin will perform with her best singles featuring a very talented Lubomir Smilenov’s virtuso play and his astounding improvisation !! "

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pNSwCLA6w5o

---------------------------------------------------------

10 pm to 12 am - LIVE GHAZAL BAND

----------------------------------------------------------

Featured : KEYZ2MUSIC

Keys 2 music promotes the music from the Sub Continent as it is, from Bollywood & Bhangra, to Gujrati Garbaa, South Indian classical to the sounds of Ghazals/Sufi Kalyam, Introducing western sounds, and fusion, Keys 2 music is changing the way people listen to music !

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------

12 am to 2;30 am - DRINK / DANCE / MOOD / GROOVE HYPNOTIC / CHILL MUSIC

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Featured : DJ S2

DJ S2 is one of the most captivating upcoming DJs from Jersey City focusing on the Indian Sub Continent Fusion Music . He will be spinnng some Mood fueled music (think Buddha Bar !) as you get entranced with some great drink specials & meet new people , chill , dance and revel in hypnotic backbeats and trance like moods.

• Tickets on sale now: https://playmusician.eventbrite.com

Cover / 21+ Only

Early Bird Online Special - $10 online

General Admission - $15 door

Venue : Transmission, 150 Bay Street, Jersey City, NJ. 07302


Near Grove Street Path Station and LightRail

For Updates & RSVP: https://www.facebook.com/events/1670186043246401/

==========================================

PLAYMUSICIAN

PlayMusician provides a platform for artists, both upcoming and established, to showcase their talent . We provide a comfortable, laid back venue with the intention of being a place where people can come together and enjoy local artists and entertainment . We help local businesses such as bars/restaurants become music venues . Playmusician has been an artist bedrock since 2010.

PlayMusician is a group that promotes local artists and musicians by creating musical events with eclectic themes and showcasing them.

Seasoned artists are matched with young up and coming musicians based on a theme.  We also promote other types of artists such as photographers, videographers, painters, comedians, dancers, etc. 

The PM  community is a growing community of artists , businesses and community  through  events, website, social media and personal networking.

What if you knew the secret to have time for both everything you NEED to do and everything you WANT to do?

If you ever wished there was a way to just multiply your free time, and stop being so overwhelmed…

Then this is THE breakthrough you’ve been waiting for!

For the first time, the secrets and mysteries of time will be revealed by a living Enlightened Master, Paramahamsa Nithyananda in a brand new workshop!

2 DAY GUIDED MEDITATION WORKSHOP by a living Enlightened Master, Paramahamsa Nithyananda, about…CONQUERING TIME! Unlocking the illusion of time, so you have time for everything. Happening LIVE around the planet

results.description:
Join multiple meetup groups (◄ and this is just a handful of the people attending) for Quiet Clubbing at Studio Square! Drinks, food, and 3 DJs spinning at the same time to keep you singing and partying all night. Don’t like what DJ 1 is playing, you’ll have two other choices to dance and have fun to. These parties tend to get wild and sell out so be sure to get your tickets fast!

Your 3 Channels will be / Your 3 DJs will be spinning: 
DJ 1 (Green): Top 40 hits, Dance, Pop, etc 
DJ 2 (Red):  The best of 80’s & 90’s, and 2K music! 
DJ 3 (Blue): Hip-Hop, R&B 

What the night includes: 
Quiet Events Headphones 
Glow in the Dark Gear 
3 Live DJs battling for your attention 

Special Notes: 
$10 Tickets are limited, so act fast! 
This party is going on rain or shine. 
Age Restriction: 21+  

 HOW IT WORKS

***Bring a credit or debit card for the check-in process*** When you arrive you’ll receive a pair of special wireless headphones. You can adjust the volume and choose between up to three DJ with a flip of a switch. Each headset has a color LED that shows what you are listening to, so you can dance along with those listening to the same DJ as you. It’s super social; just lower the volume or take the headphones off and talk to that girl or guy. There’s no loud music that you have to talk over. Plus, there’s no ringing in your ears when you leave. At the end of the night, be sure to return your headphones as there will be a $100 charge to your credit or debit card if headphones don’t come back. 

Get tickets here: <a>http://quietevents.electrostub.com/event.cfm?key=YW658U7oXE&cart&showTimingID=161062 </a>;

Your Organizer Beau will be there. Call or text upon your arrival at[masked] 

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qwyoKwhUgwk

results.description:
In this hit '80s hybrid of the horror movie and the teen flick, a single mom and her two sons become involved with a pack of vampires when they move into an offbeat Northern California town. Lucy (Dianne Wiest) and her sons, Michael (Jason Patric) and Sam (Corey Haim), move to Santa Carla to live with Lucy's lovable but curmudgeonly father (Barnard Hughes). Lucy gets a job from video-store owner Max (Edward Herrmann), then begins dating him, while Sam hangs out with Edward and Alan Frog (Corey Feldman and Jamison Newlander), a pair of vampire-obsessed comic-shop clerks. Soon Michael falls in with some actual vampires after becoming enamored of one of their victims: Star (Jami Gertz), a gypsy-like vixen who is trying to hold on to her humanity even though vampire leader David (Kiefer Sutherland) wants to play Peter Pan to her Wendy. When Michael visits the cavernous hangout of David and his cronies and unwittingly drinks from a wine bottle full of vampiric blood, he becomes an unwilling member of the bloodsucker biker gang. Soon, it's up to Sam and the Frog brothers to destroy David and his ilk without killing Michael and Star. Shot on location in the coastal California town of Santa Cruz and directed by Hollywood pro Joel Schumacher, The Lost Boys became a pop-culture phenomenon thanks to its attractive young stars, offbeat soundtrack, and hip, clever marketing campaign. The film's tagline -- "Sleep all day. Party all night. Never grow old. Never die. It's fun to be a vampire." -- perfectly captured its knowing mixture of attitude and gore. The effects team who transformed Sutherland and company into snarling bloodsuckers would go on to provide equally gruesome effects for Blade, another revisionist vampire flick, more than a decade later.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=r1Iqy6m7U7c

results.description:
On a President Day 2016 weekend several HVH hikers attempted to hike this traverse. All of them had to bail out at some point. Strong wind, cold, lack of equipment, stove that was left turned on in a cabin...casual winter hiking stuff. Few of them decided to give it another try.

1. Hiking plan

• Parking Lot - Madison - Adams

We’ll start from the parking lot on Road 2, just across the Durand Lake. We will take Valley Way, and will do our best not to lose it, until we get to the intersection with Watson Path. We’ll hike Watson Path till we reach Mount Madison. From there, it’s more or less straightforward and marked with cairns trail to Madison Spring Hut. From Madison Hut, we’ll take Star Lake Trail to Mount Adams.

• Adams - Jefferson - Clay

From Adams, we’ll follow Gulfside Trail heading to Mount Jefferson. Again we’ll do our best not to miss the right turn because just before the summit we’ll need to leave Gulfside Trail and turn to the right to grab a peak. We’ll go down from Jefferson and return to Gulfside Trail on our way to Mount Clay. Right after the intersection with Sphinx Trail, we will keep left in order to take a route that goes to the summit of Clay.

• Clay - Washington - Monroe

After we descend from Clay, we’ll take Jewell Trail all the way to Mount Washington. If we still alive and sane, we’ll try to take a few pictures there and run the heck down by Crawford path / AT. This trail will lead us to Monroe Mountain

• Monroe - Franklin - Eisenhower

They say it’s pretty easy after Monroe. Just keep to the Crawford path / AT. From Monroe to Franklin, from Franklin to Eisenhower. There will be a trident-intersection before Eisenhower. Keep to the middle for Eisenhower

• Eisenhower - Pierce

I want to grab Pierce too, so plan is to keep to Crawford path / AT even after Eisenhower.

Our finish is Crawford Connector Parking Lot

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

2. Accommodation

Every man for himself :)

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

3. Gear and Equipment

Snowshoes, trekking poles, winter boots that will keep your feet dry and warm, ski pants, ski jacket, ski mask/goggles, liner gloves, winter gloves/mittens.
Traction devices of your choice: microspikes, crampons

Goal is to keep yourself warm and at the same time reduce sweating to minimum. Oh well, let's at least try to do this. I was never able to reach this balance though :)

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------


5. Trail awareness and common sense


We all hike with different speed. I, for one, prefer to wear less clothes and move faster. Some people like to take their sweet time being all covered in proper layers.

Imagine that you are alone on a trail and you have no cell coverage. This can totally happen.

1. You'll need to figure out where you are now

2. You'll need to figure out where to go to get to the nearest bail out route

3. You'll need to figure out how to get to your car or to the cabin

Have these 3 points covered at all time

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

5. Boring stuff

You agree when you sign up for this group or any of the events that you have read and understand the below.

If you join us for a hike (or any other event), please understand that you are responsible for your own preparedness and well-being and will hold no one else liable in case of injury or mishap. You agree not to hold the Organizer, Assistant Organizers, or any other members responsible for any injuries, mishaps, or any other situation that may happen at a planned event. You are responsible to research the event, know the area, and bring the proper gear.

Your attendance on a hike signifies that you have read and accept the terms of this liability waiver.
Full waiver can be found on the ABOUT page.

results.description:
**This event is for dogs and their pet parents!

Rain, sleet, snow (sorry - snow can get the best of us sometime) or shine, FIDO in Prospect Park sets up a table full of goodies on the first Saturday of every month.  Look for coffee, pastries, dog biscuits as well as relevant information pertaining to off-leash activities and issues. And it's all FREE!

Afterwards I usually walk over to the Farmers Market at Grand Army Plaza and pickup some groceries before heading home.

venue.name: NY Route 73 / Round Pond Trailhead

results.description:
Who's organizing: Richard Williams

*** Advanced intermediate hike in Winter weather. You should have basic map and compass skills, be OK bushwhacking. The hike is entirely on well traveled herd paths, but people do get confused or on the wrong path, which then makes it a bushwhack, requiring basic off trail orienteering skills. - This should only be attempted by experienced hikers***

Itinerary: We will take the Dix mountain Via Round Pond trail to Dix mountain then we will bushwack over the heard path to Hough peak and then reverse our steps back the our cars.

Distance 15. miles

Elevation Gain 3600

Well behaved dogs welcome.

Special Gear / Requirements: non cotton wicking clothing & insulating layers dependent on forecast, water/windproofing layer, enough food for a full day (2 nights for backpackers), at least 3 liters of water, first aid, and a water filter is a good idea, you can filter at the base of Macomb slide.ADK "High Peaks Region" map & compass, headlamp & extra batteries, camera!

WARNING REGARDING BUSHWHACKS: "Bushwhacks" are hikes that go off of maintained trails and through pure wilderness. Please make sure you are very confident in your ability to navigate through the woods without trails since it is very easy to get lost in these forests, especially in the winter. Map & Compass REQUIRED. GPS is also recommended, but it is not a substitute for a map & compass and the skills to use them effectively.

Getting there: From New York State Thruway exit 24: Albany/Montreal. Immediately after the toll take the 2nd exit (exit 1N) for I-87 North towards Montreal. Stay on I-87 for 95 miles to exit 30. Turn left on Rt. 73 Parking area is on left at the sign for Round Pond.

NOTE: You are responsible for bringing appropriate gear, supplies, clothing, first aid, and lights. You should review topographic maps and trail features carefully; understanding topography of any hike is key to your knowing where you are, where you're going, and how to get back.

See suggestions for GEAR on the "About" page for additional gear ideas.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

You agree when you sign up for this group or any of the events that you have read and understand the below.

If you join us for a hike (or any other event), please understand that you are responsible for your own preparedness and well-being and will hold no one else liable in case of injury or mishap. You agree not to hold the Organizer, Assistant Organizers, or any other members responsible for any injuries, mishaps, or any other situation that may happen at a planned event. You are responsible to research the event, know the area, and bring the proper gear.

Your attendance on a hike signifies that you have read and accept the terms of this liability waiver.
Full waiver can be found on the ABOUT page.

results.description:
There are two trailheads and parking lots at the eastern end of Spruceton Rd.  We will meet in the second of these parking lots at the trailhead for the Diamond Notch Trail.  Once we begin we will follow the blue blazed Diamond Notch Trail along the West Kill for about .75 miles to Diamond Notch Falls.   This is a beautiful area for pics so we can take a quick break here if we want.

After the falls The DNT bears right but we will bear left picking up the red blazed Devil's Path Trail  This will begin the steepest climb on the hike.  The climb is about 1200 feet in about 1.3 miles.  We will begin ascending Hunter Mt and will climb from approximately 2300 feet at the falls to just over 3500 feet at Geiger Point.  This is just off a short side trail and gives views of Leavitt's Peak and West Kill Mountain.

The trail levels out quite a bit at this point but is still a gradual up hill.  about .5 miles on we should find a herd path marked by a cairn.  This leads to the summit of SW Hunter/Leavitt's Peak.  The hike to the summit, one of the Catskill 3500's is a relatively flat .75 miles each way.

After following the herd path .75 miles back to the DPT, we will bear right and very shortly arrive at the Devil's Acre Lean-to.    Just past the lean-to we will leave the Devil's Path Trail and bear left onto the yellow blazed Hunter Mt Trail.  This will begin an approximately 500 foot ascent over the next 1.5 miles or so to reach the summit of Hunter Mt as well as the fire tower.

After taking in the views and resting at the fire-tower, we can begin the descent of Hunter.  We will pickup the Blue Blazed Spruceton Trail.  The trail down is mostly an old jeep trail.  In about 1.35 miles we will come to the John Robb Lean-to where we plan to spend the night.  There are a few DEC marked tent sites behind the lean-to.  if the lean-to is taken.  This lean-to probably has the best views of any lean-to in the Catskills. It has a spectacular view over the Spruceton Valley.

After we set up camp, we can do an optional 2.5 miles round trip hike to the Colonel's Chair.  The hike is about 1.25 miles each way with a 500' decent on the way out and a 500' ascent on the way back. The Colonel's Chair is at the top of the Hunter Mt ski area.  There's also a rumored snack bar/ restaurant up there to grab a burger and fries at.

The next morning is a relatively easy and uneventful 2.75 miles back to the car.  About 2.5 of that will be down the blue blazed  Spruceton Trail/ Jeep trail and then we'll need to finish it off with about .25 miles of road walking back to the parking lot. 

Phonecia Diner to follow.

======

By RSVP'ing to this trip you are confirming your acceptance of our Group's terms.

Contact:

--------------

Responsibility of all hikers: (YOU ARE RESPONSIBLE FOR YOU) 

Hiking and other events organized by this Group are inherently risky and may result in death or serious physical or emotional injury.

Join these hikes (or other events) only at your own risk. The hike organizer and those connected to this group and this website may not be held responsible for the safety or well-being of anyone or their pets who chooses to join these events. By going with us, you agree to research the trip, and send the organizer or others questions as necessary. On the trail, we all care for each other as friends, not as guides or leaders or agents – if you sign up to come, you agree to take primary responsibility for yourself. There are no “liability waivers” or other written agreements to sign. By signing up you agree not to hold anyone responsible if something goes wrong for any reason.

The Group Leads. The Organizer Organizes. 
We do not have "trip leaders." There is, however, always an organizer who gives out as much trip event information as possible and practicable on the website event post prior to an event. Nothing replaces the collective wisdom of the group, especially in the wilderness. We work hard to strengthen our post information and advice to ensure our trip groups are matched for our hikes and that everyone in the group is ready mentally or physically for the hike and that everyone has all relevant facts before the event. As a member you can do your part - read the post carefully prior to your attendance. If you have questions, suggestions or comments, email them to your organizer well beforehand.

Hike Preparation 
You are solely responsible for researching each event and for selecting and bringing appropriate gear and supplies, including clothing, food and water, to each event. If you have any questions regarding appropriate gear or supplies, please contact the event organizer for the event. You understand that any guidance given by an organizer is done as a courtesy based on the organizer's personal experience and physical capabilities, which may not be the same as yours, and will not hold any organizer liable for guidance provided. You remain responsible for you.

Leave No Trace: 
Outdoor skills and ethics - protect our hiking resources. https://lnt.org/learn...

Children: 
Children are allowed on hikes or other events at the sole discretion of the event organizer as indicated in the event posting. You are solely responsible for all children under your care.

Identification and Insurance: 
We strongly encourage all hikers to bring along identification, medical insurance card and emergency contact names and phone numbers.

Pets: 
Domestic pets are allowed on hikes or other events at the sole discretion of the hike organizer as indicated in the hike posting. All pet owners must bring a leash along in case needed for the safety of all hikers, other pets, or your own pet. Pets must be leashed on the request of the event organizer. Pet owners are solely responsible for their pets and their actions. If you are afraid of dogs, and are attending a hike that permits dogs, please advise the hike organizer ASAP, so we can try to accommodate your needs.

Event Updates: 
By signing up to an event, you agree to check the event posting often for any updates to the event.

Waits at Trail Junctions: 
The group decides where and when to wait up for those behind - but no one joining us should always count on that. It's easy for trail junctions to be overlooked. By going with us, you agree to research the trip on your own, know where we are going and how to get back, even if for some unanticipated reason you may wind up having to do that by yourself.

Hike Pace: 
There is no set pace - you set your own. HYOH - Hike Your Own Hike.

Any hike over 10 miles will not be done as a large group hike, we will leave the parking area together but then split apart as our pace allows us to do so. All hikers are encouraged to hike at a pace they are comfortable with. Please make sure you know the route and can make it out alone if needed. If you have concerns please see the organizer before the hike starts. The organizer will wait at the end of the hike to make sure all hikers complete the hike safely.

Attendance and Lateness Policy: 
Be on time. At the discretion of the organizer, we may wait 15 minutes only for late attendees that have already signed up for an event.

Group Size: 
The group size will be determined based on the hike and the rules of the land we will be hiking on. Please update your 'YES'- or 'MAYBE' RSVP if your plans change so members on the waiting list can attend the hike.

Details:

1 game (7 v 7) : Two halves of 30 minutes each with a break in between

-Please bring a fun and chill attitude. Absolutely no rough playing, slide-tackling or berating others; You’ll be asked to leave.

-Turf, AG cleats, or sneakers - no wet ground monster spikes.

-$4.00 goes for maintaining the website, equipment, and organization.

Rules:

This is a chill game so please bring a chill attitude; no meatheads or a$$holes. Organizers have the final say (i.e. if a ball is out of bounds we call it). 
It’s a small pitch so no corners kicks; just throwins.

Directions:

How to get to Brooklyn Bridge Park PIER 2 Sports Field:

To get past the BQE, you must enter Brooklyn Bridge Park on foot either fromm the south (at Joralemon St. & Furman St.) or the north (at Old Fulton St. & Furman St.)  Pier 2 is roughly halfway between these two entrances.  We play on the artificial grass field at the far end of the pier, behind the basketball courts & roller rink.

Google these coordinates:[masked], [masked]

Brooklyn Bridge Park is accessible by several subway lines (A/C, 2/3, 4/5, F, R) and bus routes (B25, B63)

Cancellation: 

We'll play rain or shine.  We'll only cancel if there are fewer than 10 people going, or if there's lightning in the area.
results.name: Saturday 7 v 7 Soccer

results.description:
Sat. Mar. 5 th.  Cornell Mine,  RD, Timp Thorne Trails loop  2 C 7.5

The pace is slow (2  less than 2 mph),  the trail and terrain are rocky, steeps ( C)  distance 7.5 miles with elevation gain of 1800'. 

Up one of the steepest ascents in the park, the face of bald on the Cornell Mine Trail, at my persistently slow pace.  This first trail dead-ends into the RD  We go right and up shortly cresting the grand summit of Bald.  After eyeball satiation we continue on the RD  to junction with the Timp Thorne  trail almost at Thorne top .  More view. Our decent from the Gibraltar  of the park  drops us in Timp Pass.  There we decide :  do another climb,  visit some mines, or head without serious deviation for the cars.  Vertical gain is 1800 ft.  You will breathe, and if the day is sunny sweat a little.  Does Any body know why such a small town, as was Dottletown,, had two cemeteries?  We need a whole day of time.  This is not an early out hike.  So we turn to Metro North for help. Transporation 5 A.  take the EARLY train  leaving Grand Central at 7:43, with drivers meeting the train at 8:55 at the Manitou Station.  Train people remind the conductor.  From there it is  a drive of 3 or 4  miles to the road side trail head parking.  Drivers. any question regarding meeting place, I will send you a map.  City people,  unless  a driver from the city comes forward  and alerts the group,  the train is best way to get there.  Look for clean riverside windows.  I can and will offer ride sharing for return into the City most likely  along 96th Street.  Check NOAA for West Point weather: pick your layers, bring adequate water,  shoes comfortable for rocky walking, and be prepared to mediate you way  to the top of Bald with yoga breathing.  Leader Bill Hladky  [masked]  914. 874. 4640.
results.how_to_find_us: Drivers meet the train in the parking area, train riders remind the conductor, we will caravan to trail-head on 9W.
results.name: Hike South of Bear Mt  to grand view and pass through what was Dottletown

results.description:
PLEASE READ ALL THE DETAILS BEFORE YOU RSVP. INFORMATION IS NEEDED TO RESERVE YOUR SPOT.

Earth Keepers in Watchung Reservation Mountainside, Union County Department of Parks and Recreation 

<a href="http://www.jerseycares.org/HOC__Volunteer_Opportunity_Details_Page?id=a0CA000000k3zPGMAY&wrs=HOC0038-002-d09abccb-77f8-410c-8871-2c86e9fb9e01"></a>

Watchung Reservation Mountainside is a semi-wilderness oasis in the midst of a suburban development. Volunteers are needed to make a trail more accessible to hikers and to people who wish to enjoy nature. Volunteers work under the guidance of staff and all tools are provided. 

This is a rain or shine project!

NOTE:


• Wear closed toed shoes/boots

• Wear long pants instead of shorts to protect yourself while gardening

• Wear clothes you don't mind getting dirty

• Bring a hat

• Bring work gloves if possible

• Bring water and snacks

• Wear insect repellent and sunscreen

• This is a labor intensive project

If your RSVP YES, you are making a commitment to Jersey Cares and Union County Department of Parks and Recreation. Please keep your commitment. There are a certain number of spots available and they may be declining someone else so that you can participate. 

Once you get to 452 New Providence Road (Trailside Nature & Science Center) in Mountainside, please continue to the building downhill from the main parking lot (the Old Museum Building). We meet on the left side of that building. You should NOT go to Trailside’s Visitor’s Center! If you are lost or need further direction, please call Betty Ann, the agency contact person on site at[masked]-5800. Please arrive no later than 9:15am so that we don’t hold the rest of the group up.


When you RSVP, you will be asked for your FULL NAME, EMAIL, and AGE to register to volunteer. YOUR SPOT IS NOT RESERVED UNTIL WE HAVE THIS INFO.

As usual, if you cannot attend there is no need to post why. We will catch you next time. :)

results.description:
We'll meet in front of the Red Barn Bakery for a run on the Old Croton Aqueduct. Afterward, whoever is interested can head to the Red Barn Bakery for breakfast. This is a good run for new runners because it is out and back - no set distance to cover but you will need to wear a watch. Feel free to turnaround at any point or walk/run at your own pace. 

Details about the Saturday run

Route: We’ll meet in front of the Red Barn Bakery (4 S. Astor St.) in Irvington and jog VERY casually together to the Old Croton Aqueduct trail. (If you are unfamiliar with the area and would prefer to walk rather than run to the trail, click here to see the trail on a map.) From there we’ll head south toward Dobbs Ferry. There is no set distance. Everyone will walk or run at their own pace for 25 minutes, and then turn around and come back. Please wear a watch so that you know when to turn around.

Water/Bag Storage: There are very few water fountains along the route, so bring a water bottle if you need one while running. I’ll bring water and cups for after the run. There’s no bag storage, so leave belongings at home or in your car.

Location: In front of Red Barn Bakery (4 S. Astor St, Irvington, NY 10533). Free parking is available on weekends in the MetroNorth lot next door.

</a>  <a href="https://www.facebook.com/groups/1452433901730637/">Join our Facebook group to post pictures or message other members.

General advice & guidelines for our regular meetup runs:

• RSVP if you are going. If your plans change, simply change your RSVP.

• There is no bag storage, so please bring only what you plan to run with.

• All regular runs are rain or shine, unless the weather is actually dangerous.

• If you arrive late, can’t find the start location, miss us for any reason, run anyway!

Feel free to contact me either via my meetup account or at [masked] if you have any questions.

results.description:
The New York City School of Data is a collaborative network improving the City’s data ecosystem. This network seeks to enrich our lives and communities through technology, data, & design. 

This year, we invite civic hackers and community based organizations to learn from each other and share how we can improve our communities and our data.


This year’s School of Data conference is a day-long showcase of New York City’s open data ecosystem, innovative users, and a showcase of civic technology. Additionally, we have breakout rooms for you to collaborate on some of NYC’s most pressing open data issues—including a data jam to address economic and social injustice.

Join us as we celebrate the fourth anniversary of New York City’s Open Data Law and make open data and civic technology work for all of us.


NOTE - Childcare will be provided!

====


To attend this event, you must RSVP via Eventbrite < https://nycsodata16.eventbrite.com>.


====


Conference sessions this year are framed around BetaNYC’s four freedoms: connect, learn, innovate, collaborate.


Connect — internet, hardware, and things that connect to other things.

Learn — education tools, workshops, practices, and programs.

Innovate — technology, tools, data, hacking, and community uses / users.

Collaborate — policies, legislation, and the law.


====

We are working with our friends and neighbors to curate most sessions, and have a very open door. If you have an idea or suggestion, please send us a message. We want to hear from you!


Are you a student and/or need a scholarship? Send us a message!


Interested in volunteering for two hours and attending for free? Send us a message!

====

To attend this event, you must RSVP via Eventbrite < https://nycsodata16.eventbrite.com >.

results.description:
Just putting this on the calendar in a recurring fashion to allow for people to plan ahead and see if we can make more people intersect.

These will be mostly (unless highlighted) in Watching Reservation, but may occasionally detour to Loantaka, Washington Park, South Mountain and so one. 

In every case, the idea will be to be at that location at 9:30, and to be done at the very last at 10:30. Carpooling may be organized in some cases (via the FB group for efficiency). The trail will be decided when we leave. Whatever strikes our fancy, take a look at past meetups to get a sense. No runner left behind as I will be at back panting heavily anyway. 

If you're wondering wether you're up for a 1 hour run - let us know and we can shorten it or make sure we set our pace adequately. The idea is to enjoy ourselves and nature, not to set any speed records.

Note that this is a member-run meetup: no one is responsible for you but you. Your event host is not responsible for you or any injuries that could happen as you willingly run across rough terrain with roots, rocks, gullies, etc. Don't expect anyone to have first aid knowledge, supplies, or water for you. Just a bunch of like-minded people enjoying the trails together! For more details see section 6.2 of http://www.meetup.com/terms/

results.description:
PLEASE READ THIS CAREFULLY BEFORE YOU RSVP. I TAKE THE RSVP PROCESS VERY SERIOUSLY AND I EXPECT THAT YOU SHOULD TOO. 

Join me and AMC club members who do not have to RSVP, UNLESS you do not get last minute e-mails, on an adventure to Liberty and Ellis Island.  I’ve been to both places a long time ago and wanted to go back. This should be interesting and a lot of fun. There appears to be only one official way to get there. First stop would be Liberty Island and then Ellis Island. I would not be giving the tour-there are free audio tours- but we could travel as an informal group. At the end of the event, I may do a tour of the Lower Manhattan waterfront for those who want one. We’ll figure that out later.

We will be meeting at 9:30 A.M. in Lower Manhattan.

TICKETS ARE $18.00, $14.00 FOR SENIORS.

BY RSVP’ing you are making a commitment to going. I will then send you information on how to get tickets.


Please consider joining the Appalachian Mountain Club (AMC) http://www.amc-ny.org/ The Club offers many hikes, walks and events and is also active in conservation efforts and trail maintenance. Only a few of the many hikes and walks that are offered by AMC leaders are posted on Meetup. 

Let’s leave 10 spaces for AMC Meetup members. (I am going to give preference to those who have attended hikes I have led in the past). Needless to say, please take the RSVP process seriously and be considerate. If you have been a NO SHOW on any of the previous AMC Meetup events that I have led or you abuse the RSVP process –see your Attendance History- please do not sign up for this event. Unfortunately your ship has sailed. 

I am going to ask that people not post any comments or questions prior to the event. I WILL SEND THOSE WHO RSVP INFORMATION ON HOW TO GET TICKETS.

Sat Mar 5th 

The PULAD METHODof Color Crochet9:30 am – 12:30 pm  

Learn Karen’s unique color crochet techniques for creating fascinating crochet stitch patterns that allow you to work 1 row each in 2 colors without cutting your yarn. Expand your stitch pattern repertoire by leaps and bounds, including vertical stripes, bamboo stitch, 2-color checkers, dotted puffs, outlined shells, and lots more.Skill Level:  (Adv Beginner-Intermediate)

POP-UP Crochet   1:15 pm – 4:15 pm

Bumped-out stitch patterns can add real excitement to projects, and are used time and again in crochet. Incorporate these relief elements into Aran designs to make Scottish thistles, tulips, berry clusters, crown picot edging, hanging popcorns, crossed bobble cables, a lovely arch gallery, and many more fascinating patterns. Skill Level: :  (Adv Beginner-Intermediate)

results.description:
COME JOIN US AS WE HIKE SUGARLOAF AND PLATEAU MOUNTAINS IN THE NORTHERN REGION OF THE CATSKILLS. THIS WILL BE AN INTERMEDIATE WINTER CONDITION HIKE. WE WILL PASS DIBBLE'S QUARRY ON OUR APPROACH AND TRAVERSE 1/4 OF THE DEVIL'S PATH ENDING AT DEVIL'S TOMBSTONE CAMPGROUND. YOU CAN EXPECT THIS TRIP TO BE ABOUT 9 MILES. PLEASE NOTE THAT THE TRAIL CONDITIONS MAY BE STEEP AND ICY AND AT LEAST MICROSPIKES WILL BE MANDATORY ON THIS HIKE!

FOR MORE INFO CHECK THESE LINKS:

http://www.catskill-3500-club.org/catskill-peaks/sugarloaf-mountain.htm

http://www.catskill-3500-club.org/catskill-peaks/plateau-mountain.htm


WE WILL MEET TO SPOT CARS AT 9:30am SHARP AT the Devil's Tombstone Trailhead Parking Area by Notch Lake off Route 214 in Hunter, NY

WE WILL THEN CONTINUE TO OUR START POINT AT the Trailhead Parking Area off Dale Lane in Elka Park, NY


DISTANCE: Approximately 9 miles

HIKING PACE: up to 2 mph

ESTIMATED HIKE TIME: up to 5-7 hours

DIFFICULTY: Intermediate with winter conditions and icy trails

CURRENT WEATHER FORECAST: Partly Sunny with a high of 39 degrees


RECOMMENDED GEAR:

• Microspikes (and Hillsound Crampons as needed)

• Winter base layer, mid layer and outer shell (as needed)

• Gloves, Hat, Gaiters


• Headlamp with spare batteries - Lowe's has an Energizer 200 Lumen headlamp for only $19.97

• Shoes with good grip - preferably with ankle support

• A Medium Pack

• Related maps, a Compass or GPS, Water, Snacks, First Aid, etc.

• Hiking Poles



RELATED MAPS:

New York - New Jersey Trail Conference - Catskills Trails Map Set

Catskill Hiking maximum group size limitations.

• A group size limit of 12 people for day hiking off-trail or in wilderness areas is in place. Any group larger than 12 must split up (by no less than 1 mile) into smaller, self-sufficient groups that satisfy the size requirement. These groups shall not congregate into one large group at trail junctions, rest stops, lunch breaks, etc.

• In all other areas of the Catskills a group size limit of 20 is in place. Groups larger than 20 must split up (by no less than 1 mile) into smaller, self-sufficient groups that satisfy the size requirement. These groups shall not congregate into one large group at trail junctions, rest stops, lunch breaks, etc.


 NYC HIKING & OUTDOOR ADVENTURE GROUP LEGAL DISCLAIMER
Waiver of liability

You agree when you sign up for this group or any of the events that you have read and understand the below.

If you join us for a hike (or any other event), please understand that you are responsible for your own preparedness and well-being and will hold no one else liable in case of injury or mishap. You agree not to hold the Organizer, Assistant Organizers, or any other members responsible for any injuries, mishaps, or any other situation that may happen at a planned event. You are responsible to research the event, know the area, and bring the proper gear.

The NYC Hiking & Outdoor Adventure Group does not provide liability insurance for the protection of individuals who may participate in any of the events planned by the Organizer or Assistant Organizers.

This release extends and applies to, and also covers and includes, all unknown, unforeseen, unanticipated and unsuspected injuries, damages, loss and liability.

Your attendance on a hike signifies that you have read and accept the terms of this liability waiver. By signing up for this group or event you understand that you are attending all events AT YOUR OWN RISK. Organizers and Assistant Organizers of this group are just that, we organize the events and hike together as friends. There are no leaders on these hikes, you are your own leader- This is YOUR hike.

results.description:
LEADER: Peter Reiner ([masked] or[masked]) 

RATING: B 6.5 B

Meet at 9:30 AM on Johnstown Circle for a hike on the Blue Disc, Victory and White Bar Trails. Traction devices required if ice or snow.  Bad weather cancels hike. TC Harriman-Bear Mountain Trails map 118.

*   *   *   *   *   *

Our full hike schedule can be viewed on our website at hudsonhikers.org, and some hikes are also posted on our Facebook page.

After attending two hikes/events, please consider joining the North Jersey Ramapo Chapter of the Adirondack Mountain Club to support our outdoor recreation and conservation activities.  Membership comes with a variety of benefits including a 10% discount at Ramsey Outdoor; our annual holiday party and social; special events such as our traditional day-outing to the Mohonk Mountain House; a subscription to ADK’s bi-monthly magazine, Adirondac; and the opportunity to contribute to the preservation and extension of hiking lands and viewsheds in our region.

New hikers are strongly encouraged to select hikes appropriate to their capabilities. North Jersey Ramapo Chapter hikes are rated for pace (A, B or C), mileage, and terrain (A, B or C), with "C" designating easier hikes and "A" more challenging ones. We recommend that new hikers should first try a "C" or short "B" hike before undertaking a more difficult one; otherwise, you may not fully enjoy the hiking experience. If you have any doubts, please contact the hike leader in advance. 

Pace Ratings: 
     A = Fast - 2.5 mph or faster 
     B = Moderate - about 2 mph 
     C = Easy - 1.5 mph or less 

Distance: Noted in miles 

Terrain Ratings:
     A = Strenuous, long/steep climbs and descents, 
             possible rock scrambling
     B = Moderate climbs and descents
     C = Generally flat with little elevation change 

For example, a hike rated “B 7 A” is a moderately paced hike of approximately 7 miles with steep climbs and/or descents and possible rock scrambling. 

If you join us for a hike, please understand that you are responsible for your own preparedness, including ensuring that the hike is appropriate for your level of fitness, that you wear the proper clothing, and bring the proper gear, food and water (see the ADK's recommended Hiking Essentials and guidelines, below).

Leaders have the right, responsibility and sole discretion to refuse any hiker he/she deems to be not properly attired, prepared, or otherwise fit to safely complete the hike. 

HIKERS' GUIDELINES:

  Risks:  As with all physical activities, hiking involves hazards. Persons participate at their own risk and will be asked to sign a statement acknowledging that fact before starting the hike. Prior to the hike please advise the leader of any medical condition or physical impairment that could affect you during the hike.

  Footwear and Clothing:  Wear clothing suited to the weather and carry extra garments for unexpected weather conditions. Dress in thin layers so that you can adjust the number of layers as required to maintain comfort. In winter carry a wool cap and wool or polypropylene gloves or mitts and a windproof shell. Be prepared for rain. Bring a rain jacket and rain pants, preferably of the type that permits venting body moisture. Wear comfortable, sturdy boots/shoes.  Do not wear cotton garments in winter.

  Drink and Food:  Adequate hydration is important year round. Drink frequently during the hike. Carry food to enjoy during the midday lunch stop.

  Other responsibilities:  Hikers with children under 16 and new hikers are required to contact the hike leader in advance to determine if the hike is suitable for them.  Minors under 16 are welcome on day hikes when accompanied by a parent or guardian.  No person under 18 shall participate in overnight outings unless accompanied by a parent or adult sponsor over 21.  The hike leader may refuse to allow a person to hike who is judged to be poorly equipped or unable to do the published hike.  Participants should get to the hike at least 10 minutes prior to the starting time.

  Maps:  The TC number indicates a NY-NJ Trail Conference map for the area of the hike. For example: TC-118 refers to the Southern Harriman Park map.

  Abbreviations:  NCA-No Calls After . . . , Pref.- Leader’s contact preference.

  Expense Sharing:  When car-pooling, passengers are expected to offer the driver funds sufficient to cover the cost of fuel, tolls and parking fees. A $3.00 minimum per person is recommended. Most hike trailhead meeting locations can be found on NY-NJ Trail Conference maps.

  Dog-Friendly Hikes:  Pets are not permitted on hikes unless the hike description clearly states that it is "dog friendly."  If it is, all hikers with dogs must abide by park leash regulations.

NO SHOW/LATE CANCELLATION POLICY:
Please be considerate of event hosts/organizers and others who may want to attend an event by not being a "NO SHOW" (failing to show up when you've RSVP'd "yes") or a "LATE CANCEL" (changing RSVP to a "no" within 24 hours of an event).  If you have a history of No Shows and/or Late Cancels, we may have to bump you to the waiting list for meetups with limited space, in favor of those with a positive attendance history.

results.description:
Hi everyone,

Please be there 15 minutes earlier so you can get set up, and bring a white and a red t-shirt.

If this game is full click here for our calendar and see other game slots!

Thank you,

Paul

Details Below:

------------------------------------------------------

Game style and Rules:

1. HAVE FUN!!! It's SOCCER

2. We'll play (2) 30-minute games.

3. We will divide into teams based on everyone's experience and skills.

4. No ball hogging.

5. Please use turf shoes or sneakers. 

6. The games are very laid back; rough play, tackles or sliding are not allowed and will not be tolerated.

7. We'll play with corner kicks and throw-ins and 6'x15' big goals. Rotate goalies

8. If you arrive late to the game, you would have to wait until the game in progress is finished to join your team. Inserting people in the middle of the game disrupts the flow of the game, and it's not fair to players that arrived on time.

Field Location:The field is located on the corner of West 134th street and Amsterdam Ave. Click on this Google link for location: Click here.

Directions: By train: 1 train to 137th St. City College Station

Time: The game will start at the scheduled time sharp. Please be there 15 minutes earlier so we can get set up.

Late arrivals:

If you arrive late to the game, you would have to wait until the game in progress is finished to join your team. Inserting people in the middle of the game disrupts the flow of the game, and it's not fair to players that arrived on time.

Fee:

Please pay the fee through paypal. Part of the proceeds go to NYC SOCCER KIDS (we already donated new soccer balls). It also goes to pay for the site admistration, meet-up fees, cones, soccer balls, and the new goals.

Please bring:

A white t-shirt and a red t-shirt to differentiate players of each team. The filed is turf so please bring turf shoes, sneakers or all terrain shoes; cleats are not allowed!

Cancellations/Refunds:

If you won't be able to make it to the game, please change your RSVP to "NO" 48 hours before kickoff time to receive a credit for any future game (please email me to issue the credit) This is done to give other members a chance to take your spot. Thank you!

Waiting List:

If all the spots are taken, please get on the waiting list. If a spot opens up and you are on the waiting list, an automated e-mail will be sent letting you know that a spot has just openned :). You can also check our calendar for other games. Click here for calendar.

Weather Policy: Games will be cancelled if the weather conditions are severe such as snow, sleet or thunderstorms. If the game is cancelled I will send out an e-mail the morning of the game. Please check your e-mail. If you are unsure, or can't get to your e-mail, you can also text or call Mane at[masked]-6601.

See you on the pitch!

Paul

results.description:
MEET EVENT LEADER: Pat Horsch, cell day of hike only[masked]-8331.
Meet at Seeley's Pond Parking lot in the far western end of the Reservation. We will walk along the Green Brook. Hopefully we will see cascades of ice along the parallel escarpment. We will also pass by Skytop Pavillion and walk over the longest boardwalk in the Reservation. 4 to 5 miles, approx. 2 hours. Hiking boots required, bring water. Heavy rain cancels.Please watch this site on the morning of March 5 for any last minute changes/cancellations.

DIRECTIONS:
GPS address is 56 Valley Road, Berkeley Hts, NJ
Coordinates: N40° 40.17', W74° 24.19'
See the GPS map for this event to determine the best route, depending on which direction you are approaching from.
  From I-78 going EB, take exit 43.  Make a left onto Valley Road, then a right into parking lot.


From I-78 going WB, take exit 43 onto Diamond Hill Rd NB.  Go .4 miles and turn left onto Mountain Ave.  Go .2 miles and turn right onto Martins Lane, then turn right onto Union Ave, which turns into Diamond Hill Rd. SB.  In approx 1 mile, turn left onto Valley Road, then turn right into parking lot.

From Rt 22 EB take the Park Ave exit in Scotch Plains and follow signs towards I-78.  After crossing over Rt 22, stay straight on New Providence Rd (do not turn left to go to I-78).  Road changes names to Diamond Hill Rd.  About a mile after leaving 22, turn right at Valley Rd., then turn right into parking lot.

From Rt 22 WB – After passing Bowcraft Amusement Park in Scotch Plains, turn right onto Union Ave. (just past McDonald’s).  At the T, turn right onto New Providence Rd, which turns into Diamond Hill Rd.  Turn right at the next traffic light onto Valley Rd, then turn right into parking lot.  
For those familiar with the TRAILSIDE CENTER parking area: 
Exit Trailside parking lot and go straight across the road onto Coles Ave. which becomes Skytop Dr. (a winding, wooded road). Drive 2.7 miles, just over a small bridge. At the intersection of Glenside Ave, bear left onto Valley Rd. Proceed 0.2 miles and before the traffic light, turn left into the Seeley's Pond parking lot.
results.name: HIKE - Seeley's Pond/Watchung Res, Berkeley Heights

results.description:
For the most part, route follows sidewalks and paved roads but due to two hills is not suitable for wheelchairs or strollers.


Stroll Nyack's tree-lined streets and admire the Victorian architectural treasures around every corner.


Get lost in time viewing the majestic Hudson River as it rolls past this lovely village.


Nyack has unique shops and galleries, featuring antiques and crafts, as well as many fine restaurants.


The walk features good views of the Hudson River and the Tappan Zee Bridge, and goes by the homes of painter Edward Hopper and actress Helen Hayes.

Use the only hospital visitor entrance on the left, located on the South side (Sickle Ave side) of the building that is also accessible from Midland Ave.
There are many entrances into the hospital building complex.  Do NOT go to either of the emergency entrances nor to the outpatient entrances on Midland Ave or 5th Ave.


Please RSVP even if you are just considering attending so that we might get in touch with you if our plans change.  (We don't mind if you do not show up even if you've RSVPed - better safe than sorry.)


All walkers invited to participate.  View our club's website to learn all about Volkswalking at http://www.avaclubs.org/WestPoint and our club yearly calendar at  http://www.tinyurl.com/vcwpava .
results.name: Walk the Nyack NY (5 or 10 km) trail!

results.description:
To reserve your spot, register via Eventbrite: https://www.eventbrite.com/e/daylong-meditation-retreat-tickets-21259889903

Join the Mindful Astoria community for a meditation practice retreat day. Learn how to cultivate mindfulness--knowing what is happening right now within you and around you, so you can respond skillfully and with awareness--and how to bring the benefits of meditation practice into daily life.

By deepening our awareness through an extended period of meditation practice, we can let the mind settle, gently notice the habits of our mind, and meet our experience with kindness and groundedness.

The day will consist of guided instruction in several forms of mindfulness meditation, gentle stretching (suitable for all abilities), lovingkindness meditation, periods of silent practice, and time to ask questions and discuss meditation within a supportive community. Suited for new and experienced meditators alike. Chairs and yoga mats will be provided, though you may bring a meditation cushion or bench if you prefer. 

Participants are asked to keep their phones off or on silent for duration of the retreat.

There will be a 1 hour lunch period. You can bring lunch with you and eat at the church (there is a fridge and a microwave you are welcome to use) or you can go out and purchase lunch. During this time participants are asked to remain in functional silence.

Please wear comfortable clothing. Bring a water bottle and anything else you might need to be comfortable. Bring a journal/notebook or a few pieces of paper, and pen or pencil.

If you have any questions, please email [masked].

Minimum of 6, maximum of 15 participants. Register early to reserve your spot.

Tuition: $40 There are a few scholarship spots available for $35. If you would like to request a scholarship, please email [masked].

To reserve your spot, register via Eventbrite: https://www.eventbrite.com/e/daylong-meditation-retreat-tickets-21259889903


Date and location:
Saturday, March 5th, 10am-5pm.
Astoria First Presbyterian Church
23-35 Broadway Astoria, NY, 11106

Refunds & cancellations:
Notification of cancellation given by 9am on Friday March 4th: full refund minus $5 processing fee. No refunds will be issued after this time.

About the teacher:
Emily Herzlin has been practicing mindfulness meditation for thirteen years, and trained to teach Mindfulness Based Stress Reduction (MBSR) through the Center for Mindfulness at UMass Medical School. She is also a graduate of the Yearlong Immersion and Teacher Training program at the Interdependence Project. Emily teaches MBSR and related mindfulness and meditation courses throughout NYC (The Interdependence Project, Savasana Station, Astoria First, Columbia University, WeWork, and more), works with private students, and organizes Mindful Astoria, a meditation group in Astoria, Queens. Emilyherzlin.com

results.description:
When is Heeday start leading the hikes in wilderness again?? Bear with me for a few more weeks until it gets warmer! We'll squeeze in another 'Concrete Jungle' series, perhaps the last one for the season, and this time, we'll explorer little deeper into Brooklyn. We'll take a full advantage of free admissions at Brooklyn Botanical Garden (free entrance every Saturday from 10:00am to 12:00pm) and Brooklyn Museum (free admission on the first Saturday of the month). Who would not like free stuff, right!?

The group will meet outside the Prospect Park station on B, Q and S (just outside the train exit on Flatbush Ave closer to the junction of Empire Blvd... do NOT reference the map... Meetup won't let me pin-point to the exact location) at 10:00am and spend roughly 1.5~2 hours each at the garden and museum. Then, we'll walk to Grand Army Plaza and quickly check out the farmers' market before we make our way into Prospect Park.

Then, we'll have a spooky cemetery tour at Greenwood Cemetery at dusk.

We'll wrap up the day over quality craft beers at The Double Windsor.
results.name: Concrete Jungle III: Brooklyn Special

For this one we will try out another short-listed candidate for our permanent home bar - we ask you again to make the effort to PLEASE SHOW UP with an open mind, and give your honest FEEDBACK. The mgmt. at St. Pat's already knows about and is happy to match the good experience we've had at our previous location, so let's show them we mean business by showing up this Sat. - their page http://stpatspubnyc.com for your reference.

We realize the reviews of the last four Liga meetups have been almost unanimously good, but as a group we need to "see the other side" to feel confident in choosing the right place for us - so again, constructive reviews about things like TVs/sound, drinks/food service, transportation (which we know is important to a lot of you), etc., are all welcomed.

results.description:
**INDOOR, FUTSAL OR SNEAKERS**  

                               NO CLEATS or PLASTIC STUDS!

         NON-COMPETITIVE CO-ED PICKUP SOCCER GAMES 

                                      @ RIVERSIDE Park!

                             See our page on Facebook!:

                        ManhattanInternationalCoedSoccer

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RQxq4zYJDFg

DESCRIPTION:

Our games are for all levels and people that prefer to play a non-competitive game of soccer, break a sweat while exercising running up and down the field with the ball and all this happening in a very laid-back and non-judgmental environment. Please, arrive 10 minutes before the game so we can get the teams set up.

We'll play 3 simultaneous games of 8 on 8, with goals. There will be 6 teams on the field and we will play three games, 30 minutes/game. Every 30 minutes we will have a short break and teams will switch to play against different team. Please check your email or our meetup message board on friday night or before 12.00pm on Saturday to see what team you are on. This will save us a lot of time on the field.

RULES OF THE GAME:

First and most important rule of the game is to have fun and enjoy the time on the field! Rough play and offensive language will absolutely not be tolerated!!! In plain words, no slide tackling, no pushing and no telling off.

No power shots allowed. No power shots means; you can shoot the ball but not as hard as you can. This doesn't mean that you can not take the shot at all. Kicking the ball or taking the shot on the goal, is of course allowed.

If you don't sign up for the game, do not show up.

If you are late for the game, you must wait until the game in progress is over to join your team.

Those that don't comply with these rules, will kindly be asked to leave the field so others can enjoy the game and maybe a two game ban.

Any other questions regarding the rules of the game or anything else, should be directed to the organizer directly or to the assistant organizer/s!!!

Location:

Riverside Park at West 107 & 108 Street

Take the 1 RED Line Train to Cathedral Pkwy an walk two blocks down, to 108th Street and Riverside Dr.

The field is down the lower level near the river. You can easly access the field from 108th Street. Remember, the field is not visable from the street level, you have to walk down the stairs from Riverside Dr & 108th Street. and you will see the newly renovated fanced-in soccer field next to the river.

Call me if you can’t find the field - [masked] Manny S.


What to bring with you:

A pair of sneakers, indoor or turf shoes, shin guards (recommended) and lots of water. There is a water fountain next to the park if you need extra water.

Fee:

You will be asked to pay $9.50 when you RSVP. This $9.50 is used to pay for, facilities permits, meetup fees, Amazon fees, goals, cones, soccer balls etc.

Refunds & Weather Policy:

Refunds will be issued if the RSVP is changed by Wednesday before 12.00PM or if the game is cancelled. The game can be cancelled if the weather conditions are severe like heavy rain, snow or thunder.

After the game we'll head to a local bar for brunch and a Pint or Two.

                                        Lion’s Head Tavern


                                     995 Amsterdam Ave

                                      New York, NY 10025

                                           (212)[masked]

PARTICIPATING IN MANHATTAN-INTERNATIONAL-COED-SOCCER ACTIVITIES AGREEMENT:

I certify that I have no known medical or other conditions that could interfere with my participation in Manhattan-International-COED-Soccer activities. I also understand and accept that the practice of soccer, both indoor and outdoor, involves certain risks of physical injury. Therefore, I, individually, hereby release and discharge, Manhattan-International-COED-Soccer Organizer and Assistant Organizers from any and all claims, actions, damages, losses, liabilities, costs and expenses of any kind whatsoever, including but not limited to any claims of negligence, arising out of, resulting from, by reason of, or in connection with my participation in any of Manhattan-International-COED-Soccer programs or activities. Manhattan-International-COED-Soccer Organizer and its Assistant Organizers reserve the right to take and utilize photographs, video, or any type of recording of participating person while engaged in our or associated activities. I consent to Manhattan-International-COED-Soccer use the photograph, video, or recording of me, for advertising, promotional, or related purposes, and waive all rights to compensation and other rights which may arise as a result.

results.description:
Studying for the application process at Fullstack Academy or Grace Hopper Academy? Join the workshop that takes you through the coding assessment step-by-step. We'll review the challenges and run through practice problems, answering questions along the way. 

At the end of the session, you'll feel more confident in your skills and be ready to take the next step towards becoming a developer. 

Get a better sense for the application requirements on the Admissions Prep Materials page.

Workshop Agenda

1. Welcome from Instructors

2. Test-taking strategies: tips on how to ace the admissions coding assessment

3. Coding Challenges: attendees will pair up to solve the 5+ problems in 20 minute blocks

4. Each problem will be followed by a 10 minute review to address the solution

5. Attendees will leave the workshop having completed several coding challenges and receive Review Videos

Reminders

• Bring a computer!

• Workshop begins at 10am on Saturday

• We aren't providing a lunch break, so bring snacks to tide you over!

• Please arrive on time to maximize the effectiveness of the workshop

If you are a beginner, we recommend you complete as many of the following units 1, 2, 3, 5 and 6 of Codecademy's JavaScript track as possible before Saturday.

Grace Hopper Academy is the world’s first immersive coding school for women where students only pay tuition after securing a job. Our mission is to close the gender gap in technology through high-quality education, mentorship, and need-blind admissions. With a proven curriculum and educational program leveraged from partner school Fullstack Academy, Grace Hopper Academy offers an open environment for women to learn software development and become professional engineers.
results.name: Fullstack Academy and Grace Hopper Academy Admissions Prep Workshop

Bring your own ipod & earbuds--everybody listens to their own music as we dance walk around the park loop. What is "dance walking"? It's an improvised form of walking, with music, doing whatever movement comes naturally. It's walking and moving your arms. Or skipping, skitching, low-stepping, sideways running. It's responding to the rhythm, attitude, or story of the music you're hearing. In short, it's having a dance party in your living room, while walking through the park--hilarious and exhilarating. Alas our first meetup!

Though it is a meet and greet, everyone will have a shooting op with Natalia. 

The event starts at 10:30, we'll meet at the entrance to the park by the Lion Heads. 

I'm looking forward to introducing myself to the group and presenting Natalia as well. 

This event is a free promotional event.  Natalia has agreed to model to promote herself and the group free of charge. Please consider her work for the day and if you feel compelled to give her a generous tip, I won't stop you.   

Don't bother tipping me, and don't expect me to model -- ha ha! 

The purpose of the event is to get the group moving and to allow photographers to come up with ideas or themes for future shoots. The models then will pick up on the suggested ideas and present them to the group as photoshoots.  I will have more detail of this process when we meet including how the models get paid and the type of model release/image license agreement signed between model and photographer. 

Human nature has prevailed in all my groups when an event is free, a multitude of people will RSVP but only a small percentage shows up.  If you can not make this event, PLEASE update your RSVP.  And if you RSVP, please don't change your mind at the last minute. 

The following are pictures I took of Natalia almost 2 weeks ago for a test shoot.  She was marvelous, great posing skills and followed instructions well.  

All test shoots are done with very little makeup and are intended to catch the models posing agility and comfort with the camera. In that short hour I spent with Natalia, I spent most of my time interviewing her than shooting.  I didn't need any more than the 20 minutes I used shooting to know she' a natural. 

A big warm welcome to Natalia!

Paul

Details Below:

Game style and Rules:

1. HAVE FUN!!! It's SOCCER

4. No ball hogging.

8. If you arrive late to the game, you would have to wait until the game in progress is finished to join your team. Inserting people in the middle of the game disrupts the flow of the game, and it's not fair to players that arrived on time.

If you arrive late to the game, you would have to wait until the game in progress is finished to join your team. Inserting people in the middle of the game disrupts the flow of the game, and it's not fair to players that arrived on time.

Please pay the fee through paypal. Part of the proceeds go to NYC SOCCER KIDS (we already donated new soccer balls). It also goes to pay for the site admistration, meet-up fees, cones, soccer balls, and the new goals.

Club Hours: Gotham Archery has reserved space for us from 11:00am to 1:00pm. Those are the official club hours. Everyone is free to stay longer at the regular range rate.

First-Timers: If it is your first time at Gotham Archery, you will have to take a safety & intro lesson class from the range staff and demonstrate safe shooting. No exceptions. Please arrive 15 minutes early; the class will start promptly at 11:00am.

Public Transportation: Gotham Archery is located at 480 Baltic St (Brooklyn, NY 11217) in Gowanus. It's a few blocks south-west of the Atlantic Av-Barclays Ctr train station. The 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, B, D, N, Q and R trains all stop there.

By car from LI:You can take the LIE, Northern State or Southern State to either Jackie Robinson or the BQE.  Set your GPS to 480 Baltic Street, NY, 11217.  The parking on Sat. AM isn't bad at all: you may have to circle the block once or twice.  The building is painted in a somber yellow ochre.

BUT: please consider car pooling or training it: the drive is awful; the train is lovely.  Most LI LIRR stations suspend parking fees on Sat and Sun.

You change at Jamaica and get in at the Atlantic Terminal in Brooklyn-- walk south for about 7-8 minutes to Baltic -- go right.  Gotham is on the left.  The first time you walk here, you should have your GPS active.


 Range Costs: Make sure to mention when you pay for range time you are shooting with the NYC Archery Group to get the CLUB ONLY rate: $20 for two hours of shooting, $5 for equipment (plus sales tax). These discounts only apply during official club hours.

results.description:
Happy March!!

This week we'll continue our look at the Foundations of Mindfulness and look at Thinking as it impacts our meditation practice.

Whether we’re new to meditation or have a daily meditation practice, we all will have firsthand experience with the dual role thinking and thoughts can play. Thinking, on one hand, is an amazing tool we have for remembering, discerning, planning, goal-setting, strategizing, and problem solving. On the other hand we also know thinking as a jumbled, wandering, repetitive, and rebellious storm of mental activity that is anything but helpful or useful. We know the "Monkey Mind."

It sometimes seems that the goal of meditation must be to get rid of our thoughts, but that is not really the case. The goal is to expand our awareness and understanding of actual experience and develop our mental skills so we can actually stay present and engaged and not be led astray by that monkey. Thoughts will always continue to come and go, but with practice they will not distract us.

It is important to remember to bring compassion, kindness, gentleness and patience to our work with the thinking minds and thoughts.  A sense of humor doesn’t hurt either. By remembering that everyone faces the same challenges of mind (it's not a personal failing), we all can realize a peaceful co-existence with those challenges - with practice.

Class Structure:  

Each class begins with a very brief guided meditation of gathering and quieting followed by a topical teaching and an expanded guided mindfulness meditation. There is time for discussion and Q&A.  Please note that while there is benefit in participating in regular sittings and practice, you do not have to attend every class to find value. 

Fee by donation: Suggested starting donation is $10 and your generosity is greatly appreciated.  No one is ever turned away for lack of funds.  The donation box is on the sign-in table.

I hope you'll share your Saturday morning with us.

Foundations of Mindfulness Mindfulness is more than just paying attention. It is powered by intention, but we also have to get out of our own way to experience clearly what’s actually appearing. We have to find an openness of heart and mind and suspend our judgements and theories and rationales so we can see more than what we always see. We have to begin to relinquish the "I" and "mine" kinds of ownership over what arises in our experience. We also have to unhook from the time line that may bind us to the past or project us to the future and be mindful now.

Over the next few weeks we will explore of the traditional Foundations of Mindfulness.

Introduction to Mindfulness
Mindfulness of the Breath
Mindfulness of the Body
Mindfulness of Emotions
Mindfulness of Thinking
Mindfulness of the Mind
Mindfulness in Daily Life
results.name: Foundations of Mindfulness - Thinking

group.name: Meditation and Mindfulness in Bay Ridge

results.description:
One of the most fundamental findings of quantum theory is that particles do not obey classical Boltzmann statistics. Rather they obey 2 different statistics depending on their spin. Dr Jeff Jones will elucidate this baffling result.

We will start by examining how causality is enforced in Quantum Field Theory.  The Hilbert space of states in QFT is built out of local operators at each point in space-time.  These operators do not commute with each other so how can we be sure that a measurement at some spacetime point in the future cannot affect the outcome of another measurement in the past?  Such violation of causality is prevented by a delicate cancellation between probability amplitudes for particles and antiparticles to propagate between the 2 points.  We will see how this works in the case of spinless particles, and then move on to discuss spinors and the solutions to the Dirac equation.  This will lead up to the spin statistics theorem which explains why bosons must have integer spin and fermions half-integer spin.

DIRECTIONS:

From NYC by car: take the Holland Tunnel; after tunnel at 2nd traffic light turn left into Marin Blvrd; 1st traffic light turn left into 6th street/Thomas Gangemi Dr; 3rd traffic light turn right into Washington Blvrd; 2nd traffic light turn left into 2nd street; the Portofino is the 1st building on the right. Total distance from the tunnel ~1 mile.

From NYC by PATH train: take the PATH train to Hoboken/Journal Square from 6th Ave and 9, 14, 23 or 32 street; get of at Newport/Pavonia (2nd stop in NJ). Train ride just under 20 minutes. Cross the small park in front of the station, go left on Washington Blvrd about 0.2 miles; left into 2nd street; the Portofino is the 1st building on the right.

Tell the concierge you are going to the quantum theory meeting in the 5th floor community room.

Light refreshments will be served. If you are considering brunch, there are plenty of excellent restaurants nearby.

Any questions: call me on[masked]-2004.

Cheers,

Moshe Rozenblit
results.name: Causality and Spin in Quantum Field Theory

results.description:
Hi every pony!!! Since warmer weather continues to be upon us, why not join us on another day hiking! This time out in the great city of Manehattan!
This time we will be going in to see some of the inner parts of the city. During our trot we will be sightseeing some cool parts of lower Manhattan! In this hike we will be covering- City Hall, Chinatown, Little Italy, and the Bowery!

There will be a few stops to admire the sights and shops, so we will be able to talk about what we see.


We will all collectively meet inside The Fulton Center


Yes we are moving the usual meeting spot to another location for the start of the hike. You can get to Fulton Center with the following subway lines:
A - C - J - Z - R - 2 - 3 - 4 - 5


We will leave 30 minutes, past the hour. So get there EARLY!
NOTE: We will NOT be waiting on anyone past 11:30 AM. It is unfair for those who get here early, so please plan to get here early. If you will be late, please Un-RSVP from the event, catching up with the rest of the group would be neigh impossible.

We will make our first trek from the Fulton Center to City Hall. Working our way through the many districts.


Lastly we will head into Washington Square Park where we will take one last group shot. From there we draw the meetup to a close. After we finish our hike and make it back to where we began, we will get down into a local eatery to cool down, chat, relax, and regain our energy from our successful hike before we break off and say our farewells. No one is obligated to stay if they are scheduled to be somewhere else though ^^.

Note that there is another meetup following later in the day at 7PM for the Zootopia Movie Viewing.

Check over on event page for ticket details.

Notice about necessary fare: For use, the NYC subway will cost $2.75 per ride.

As a recommendation it is important to keep well hydrated. Bringing along some bottled water is advisable. There is some water fountains in the parks, but the first option is highly recommended, this time.
Other recommendations would be possibly a light snack if you get a munchies moment while on the hike, also a small towel.
Any other questions or recommendations, please let us know in the comments! Phone number will be posted on the morning of the Meetup. We look forward to seeing every pony again!
results.name: The Trotting Crusaders of NYC

Calling all poets! Jersey City is now offering a weekly poetry workshop. 

This workshop will start by critiquing 3-4 poems, one by each person signed up ahead of time. The workshop will end, if time permits, with one 10 minute writing prompt (an idea to incorporate into a poem written on the spot).  Poets who sign up to be workshopped must bring printed copies of their poems for the group (recommended: 10 copies). To sign up for a workshop in advance, please contact Sarah Jewell at [masked]. 

While workshopping poems, we will “mind our P’s and Q’s” by Praising first what works in a poem, and then Questioning what might be improved. This helps to keep the feedback positive and constructive. If you are new to critiquing poetry, please see these guidelines:
http://triadwriters.org/inspiration/guidelines-critique-of-poem/
